4D5319F958FF47D98CD67012DA4D0168.description:
Create and solve a problem for which data can be collected
from individuals in the class, at home, in the school, or within
the community and give a presentation of how the collection,
organization, display, and analysis of data were done to attain
a solution to the problem.

89348B056A824F33965D582E66985CDA.description:
Create a pictograph (using one-to-one correspondence) to
display collected data and make and support conclusions
based on the graph.

AB9F00904FAE419DA0FABFA92742B6B8.description:
Create a concrete graph to display collected data and make
and support conclusions based upon the graph.

037EEB39BB6E43FD9832D16766D12163.description:
Analyze pictographs to identify and define the common
attributes of a pictograph.

C7D54254C3F74BB2A7B9418BBEA0C81E.description:
Analyze concrete graphs to identify and define the common
attributes of a concrete graph.

221129176A874D7599CBB78A10E0A692.description:
Pose questions related to gathered data and explain how the
data can be used to answer those questions.

A852F521EF8445A59992ABF7570F03CD.description:
Select an organizational structure, such as sets of concrete
objects, tallies, checkmarks, charts, or lists, for the collection
of data that are gathered.

B465BB65FEF647D7BB01EF735C95203E.description:
Formulate a question relevant to one’s self, family, or
community that can be answered by gathering information
from people.

95A1ED22608541FF844FA35D4918A2A9.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of concrete
graphs and pictographs.
[C, CN, PS, R, V]

8EDACDC6B0084077BD9D3F16D396965B.description:
Analyze and correct the statement “The tissue box is a
rectangle”.

6BEEB9D8096F4417B8FF327A6721655F.description:
Analyze (using concrete models of 3-D objects) a set of
descriptions of the 2-D faces of a 3-D object to identify the 3-D
object (e.g., “A 3-D object has one rectangular face and four
triangular faces – what type of object is it?” “A pyramid.”).

2E0D677EB622420FB89BBDD9195820A3.description:
Describe the faces of a personally relevant 3-D object by
comparing the faces to 2-D shapes (such as triangles, squares,
rectangles, or circles).

78A9F2707DF24472813A9B0FB02BB9E2.description:
Analyze a set of objects and/or pictures of shapes to identify
two common attributes of each member of the set.

CE150E5F6CAA430F9D85277FBF293FDA.description:
Analyze the differences between two pre-sorted sets of objects
and/or pictures of shapes and explain how the objects and
shapes were sorted.

A128200363F74AC180A81CF401510E01.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of the
relationship between 2-D
shapes and 3-D objects.
[C, CN, R, V]

1A2BECF154A44195A208BFC8830B99B5.description:
Sort regular and irregular 2-D shapes according to two
attributes and explain the sorting rule used.

B2EC440DE5A34E21A0C46F7A85C63688.description: Create a model to represent a 2-D shape.

5388FAFF1BF24B07959572850B0A0B83.description:
Classify 2-D shapes arranged in different orientations
according to the type (triangle, rectangle, square, or circle)
and explain the impact of the orientation of shape on its
classification.

75648F8A50334D8B941BF576CE05BEB5.description:
Compare two 2-D shapes of the same type (e.g., both are
circles) and explain how the dimensions of the shapes can be
used to compare the shapes (one-to-one correspondence or
non-standard units).

1D1D896F170C4E2C9BC725D47EA75D6F.description:
Critique the statement “A 2-D shape can either be a rectangle
or a square, but not both”.

BBF2D266094C46E88809F7F5D0EC5F73.description:
Compare the attributes of triangles, squares, rectangles, and
circles and generalize descriptions of each category of 2-D
shapes objects.

AFDF02FFA4D24026B4952F1EED1ECED0.description:
Identify examples of triangles, rectangles, squares, and circles
as found in personal experiences.

E56286D9F5674EF7AF62B59ED84C8015.description:
Describe, compare,
and construct 2-D shapes,
including:
• triangles
• squares
• rectangles
• circles.
[C, CN, R, V]

DBA7018D54334A4F9F5F66580F186ABC.description:
Sort 3-D objects according to two attributes and explain the
sorting rule used.

CC9839910BFE45BB8F0492CAF280118C.description:
Create and describe a concrete representation of a personally
relevant 3-D object.

C13C218B352140ABAB9326806EF97F20.description:
Compare two 3-D objects in different orientations (e.g., “If I
was to flip this object over, the two objects would have the
same height.”).

11600A1C81204D538C152788981D590E.description:
Compare two 3-D objects of the same type (e.g., both are
cylinders) and explain how the dimensions of the objects can
be used to compare the objects (one-to-one correspondence
or non-standard units).

755C37FEA2B14AD7AC4B0D7F8A9FB1E4.description:
Compare the attributes of cubes, spheres, cones, cylinders,
and pyramids and generalize descriptions of each category of
3-D objects.

5E6AA8434B2C42D5B4509D07230A06FC.description:
Sort a set of personally relevant 3-D objects and explain the
sorting rule used.

245B4D447922436EB00EE6E39F7629EF.description:
Identify examples of cubes, spheres, cones, cylinders, and
pyramids as found in the classroom, home, and community.

528644C342E5409ABB26391C0DDA50FC.description:
Describe, compare,
and construct 3-D objects,
including:
• cubes
• spheres
• cones
• cylinders
• pyramids.
[C, CN, R, V]

E415824F8DAA4A45990C37B3E528D4C2.description:
Compare and order sets of related objects according to mass
measurements and explain the reasoning.

A58ED869C47944FABEA87B438F07CFC3.description:
Explain why the same non-standard unit should be used to
determine mass measurements that are to be compared.

F0981CE6253E40418DB8729D683E1C3F.description:
Compare estimates of the mass of the same object determined
using different standard units and provide reasons for different
values being stated for the measurements.

68D645483A50451BB6ACBDCCC542C955.description:
Identify a non-standard unit for measuring mass that would
not be a good choice in a particular situation and explain the
reasoning (e.g., to measure the mass of a desk, it would not
make sense to use an eraser as the standard unit because a
desk has so much more mass than an eraser and so it would
take too many erasers, or to measure the mass of a library
book using the standard unit of a student in the class because
the student already has a greater mass than the book).

88690CECAF61425E86F999536DD7B273.description:
Estimate the mass of a personally relevant object using one’s
own choice of standard unit.

E6CA247785644A22A9CC816C24A58EDC.description:
Defend the choice of a non-standard unit for measuring a
mass in a situation relevant to one’s self, family, or community.

3C38EA9688B64407BAEEC7FC5A95D0F6.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of non-standard
units for measurement of mass
by:
• describing the choice and
appropriate use of nonstandard units
• estimating
• measuring
• comparing and analyzing
measurements.
[C, CN, ME, R, V]

F7C63A56299A40DCA0DB6ED67D79D884.description:
Compare and order sets of related objects, possibly including
people, according to a length measurement.

5EC336DAABD0444C969953E3CE5DB500.description:
Explain why the same non-standard unit should be used to
determine length measurements that are to be compared.

6AA51FF41747411B8CB2266D2D50D8EB.description:
Explain why overlapping or leaving gaps does not result in
accurate measurements.

BF877F09A46F4B4C9AFA155D823DAF59.description:
Devise and apply strategies for determining estimates for linear
and non-linear lengths using non-standard units.

9B5F6207B6F147BC914009334EF07A4A.description:
Critique the statement “It is possible to get an exact length
measurement”.

81C9055C24D745DAA36CB4F1560623C2.description:
Compare estimates of the same length made by different units
and provide reasons for different values being stated for the
measurements.

2A2C847860D645F3A9E79B90B796D3F9.description:
Estimate a personally relevant length, including the distance
around a space, using one’s own choice of standard unit.

8A5B6293B9E1409D85E4E135ED9848C6.description:
Defend the choice of a non-standard unit for measuring a
length in a situation relevant to one’s self, family, or community.

6A6607358476464488B59F86F2D41156.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of nonstandard units for linear
measurement by:
• describing the choice and
appropriate use of nonstandard units
• estimating
• measuring
• comparing and analyzing
measurements.
[C, CN, ME, R, V]

8EB3A35C7CED482A8CAA79B9EBE41F5D.description:
Create statements of equality and non-equality and model
the statements to verify the relationship.

2D92785B69B24384B4D3FE2461B1EFC0.description:
Model two number expressions to determine if the
expressions are equal (=) or not equal (≠) and write a number
sentence to show the relationship (e.g., 3 + 2 and 4 + 1 are
both equal to 5, so the two expressions are = and I write 3 + 2
= 4 + 1; 7 - 5 and 3 are not the same quantity, so I write 7 – 5
≠ 3).

1DADA4700C694B63AD1E19BCE2BA9981.description:
Analyze and sort sets according to equality and explain the
reasoning.

72ED14D3C6C44B0796FD3F0CF3BD4B5D.description:
Analyze the impact of making changes (equal and unequal)
to both of two equal sets upon the equality of the sets.

DD23790EE1424E35A1200EB992C0859D.description:
Analyze the impact of changing one of two equal sets upon
the equality of the two sets.

6E86E77C2BDE4B0F88DC4C2BB3E7BFA5.description:
Construct two unequal sets using identical objects and verify
orally and concretely that the sets are not equal.

DAE9A3AC69CE4A1B93B9B303DE0B2C3D.description:
Compare two quantities of the same object (same shape and
mass) by using a balance scale to determine if the quantities
are equal or not.

D40C72278F534BF09A58047B01D06A47.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of equality
and inequality concretely and
pictorially (0 to 100) by:
• relating equality and
inequality to balance
• comparing sets
• recording equalities with
an equal sign
• recording inequalities with
a not equal sign
• solving problems involving
equality and inequality.
[C, CN, R, V]

E1724F8497A947B493633B3F5980E0F8.description:
Create an increasing pattern, represent the pattern in
different modes (using manipulatives, diagrams, sounds,
actions, and/or physical movements), and explain the pattern
rule.

4D5CF26CFA4E4E8FB6DAA8CB843E86C8.description:
Solve problems involving increasing patterns (e.g., determine
the house number for a particular house given the house
numbers for the other homes on the block, or determining
the number of cubes in the missing structure) and explain the
reasoning.

8DE36CFF594C4BA2953E95FBD8758C01.description:
Reproduce a concrete or pictorial increasing pattern using
numbers and explain the reasoning.

2D4901F4E99C4A7FB1E300A85AAD8C01.description:
Reproduce an increasing numerical pattern using an alternate
form (e.g., sound, action, concrete objects, or diagrams) and
explain the reasoning.

A3215E1C96BA4DEB9EB347C3B9146F4F.description:
Analyze a non-numerical increasing pattern and extend the
pattern.

BCCD19BBD75F43FC82BB4D5AD3A8D830.description:
Analyze a numerical increasing pattern for its pattern rule and
extend the pattern.

59FA0797485042E38B551BA97D9E6052.description:
Identify and describe increasing patterns in familiar situations
(e.g., hundred chart, number line, addition tables, calendar, a
tiling pattern or drawings, apartment numbers, years, or age).

DFA1E7053C2546D88BAC217F6B647A86.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of increasing
patterns by:
• describing
• reproducing
• extending
• creating patterns using
manipulatives, pictures,
sounds, and actions
(numbers to 100).
[C, CN, PS, R, V]

383776C8E1DC41A0954B25E21A8A21B2.description:
Analyze two repeating patterns that are represented using
different materials or modes (e.g., a diagram of a repeating
pattern with a core of red, red, blue, blue, blue and a sound
pattern with a core of buzz, buzz, snap, snap, snap) and
present ways in which the patterns are related (e.g., there are
two different elements in the core of each pattern, and the
core pattern is element 1, element 1, element 2, element 2,
element 2 in both patterns).

37B31C78FB1D433AB9AF273A3317A1D8.description:
Predict an upcoming element in a repeating pattern and
verify the prediction.

A497434619924B6695EFD30D34398F3D.description: Create a repeating pattern and explain the reasoning.

9A713A7754434EB49DB65FA191886D5A.description:
Analyze an intended repeating pattern to identify possible
errors.

6E52290FCE734C7291520340433CF2F3.description:
Analyze a repeating pattern for its core and extend the
pattern so the core appears twice more.

24907142B3C24F498029B928D964AE92.description:
Analyze a repeating pattern to identify the core of the
pattern.

987E94C2A8B54E34B7085F8719A0B407.description:
Identify and describe repeating patterns found in familiar
situations and justify why the descriptions are those of
repeating patterns (e.g., “Every day I get up, brush my hair,
wash my face, have breakfast” - this is a repeating pattern
because I do the same pattern over and over again).

00001F0ECF294A2E990E34ADD6ACB34F.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of repeating
patterns (three to five
elements) by:
• describing
• representing patterns in
alternate modes
• extending
• comparing
• creating patterns using
manipulatives, pictures,
sounds, and actions.
[C, CN, PS, R, V]

892682B3CAFB4B5FBF957C40BAE2271B.description:
building on a known double (e.g., 6 + 6 = 12, so 6 + 7 = 12
+ 1 = 13).

4660A4E4C3D34FE394EF48013AEC4F60.description: doubles take away two (e.g., for 4 + 6, think 6 + 6 – 2)

4CDEC8145CCA46BBB0C8B2ABE486422F.description: doubles take away one (e.g., for 4 + 5, think 5 + 5 – 1)

4CBD891AE450485C822978F2702AC989.description:
Select and explain a mental mathematics strategy that
can be used to determine a sum of up to 18 (or related
difference):

8AEB8FDC88434B75904C7EF211B0B430.description:
Critique the statement “You can add or subtract numbers
in any order and still get the same answer” and provide
examples to support the critique.

2FD8E316537542F4A4C6962FA1250963.description:
Create, model symbolically (and concretely, pictorially,
or physically if desired), and solve addition and subtraction
problems related to situations relevant to one’s self, family, or
community.

9BFC9C5E6FCC4D79A12BE5EE270BCD2A.description:
Generalize and apply strategies for adding and subtracting 1
and 2-digit numbers (with answers to 100).

D86803C7B99A46E9B9C5897E6D398F07.description:
Model concretely, pictorially, or physically situations that
involve the addition or subtraction of 1 and 2-digit numbers
(with answers to 100) and explain how to record the process
shown in the model symbolically.

39EDF21812FF4F5BB0D4501E72510C80.description:
Verify rules generalized for addition and subtraction involving
a quantity of zero.

818663614788490082CCAAB9E5EB5C27.description:
Generalize rules for adding when one addend is zero and for
subtracting zero from a quantity and use concrete, pictorial,
physical, or oral models to explain the reasoning.

A68F54985D9B4A07A703343AA972DA4B.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of addition
(limited to 1 and 2-digit
numerals) with answers to
100 and the corresponding
subtraction by:
• representing strategies for
adding and subtracting
concretely, pictorially, and
symbolically
• creating and solving
problems involving
addition and subtraction
• estimating
• using personal strategies
for adding and subtracting
with and without the
support of manipulatives
• analyzing the effect of
adding or subtracting zero
• analyzing the effect of the ordering of the quantities
(addends, minuends,
and subtrahends) in
addition and subtraction
statements.
[C, CN, ME, PS, R, V]

8A725505A52946B8B7A05D4E59443A50.description:
Demonstrate how to count objects using groupings of 10s
and 1s and explain how those groups help in the writing of
the 2-digit number that represents the quantity of objects.

0456615969BD47C68327DBFDF77D8A50.description:
Defend the statement “The value of a digit depends on its
placement within a numeral”.

4AC666FAC7C549F197952ED033514B48.description:
Explain, using concrete or pictorial representations, the
meaning of each digit within a 2-digit numeral with both
digits the same (e.g., for the numeral 22, the first digit
represents two tens - twenty counters - and the second digit
represents two ones - two counters).

42CF5178B9A9481F98EDF88BE345C081.description:
Create representations of different decompositions of the
same quantity and explain how the representations represent
the same amount.

AB25F65F682042D896AC591973025D39.description:
Represent a 2-digit numeral using ten frames or other
proportional base ten materials.

361694EF53A84A21912964177C01BE6A.description:
Critique the statement “A referent for 10 is always a good
referent to use”.

D38126FDA2D54B5298ADDB0A6A0A97AB.description:
Select a referent for determining a particular quantity and
explain the choice.

BC0FEB920D054EBD985AE74A2A3D1DA6.description:
Estimate a quantity from one’s life, family, or community by
using a referent (known quantity), including 10, and explain
the strategies used.

FD2A8231E5C44117BEA6F7E83C8CE926.description:
Analyze a number relevant to one’s self, family, or community
to determine if it is odd or even and verify the conclusion by
using concrete, pictorial, or physical representations.

C49AEA6ECE0A40EDB21B4525BAC3DB04.description:
Order a set of personally relevant numbers in ascending or
descending order and verify the resulting sequence (e.g.,
using a hundred chart, number line, ten frames, or place
value).

7200C5150AE14B53867C07B060528DB1.description:
Hypothesize and verify strategies for skip counting by
10s beginning at any whole number from 0 to 9 (e.g., in
a hundred chart, the skip counted numbers always lie
on a vertical line; using base ten blocks, skip counting
by 10s always increases the number of rods by one; or
using numerals, the tens place value always increases by 1
(meaning 10) when skip counting by 10s forwards).

88CAC87B274341E98DE20F2E888DB629.description:
Sort a set of personally relevant numbers into odd and even
numbers.

73F4D240CA504C94936447CD35A9010C.description:
Analyze an ordered number sequence (including a hundred
chart) for errors or omissions and explain the reasoning.

9C98C82AEB6A4CDD965EB1F6F7D77493.description:
Analyze a sequence of numbers in order to describe the
sequence in terms of a skip counting strategy (by 2s, 5s,
or 10s as well as forward and backward) and extend the
sequence using the pattern.

7649C4A73D7B4CCFB4C1CE3E390F60C0.description:
Write numbers to twenty in words when said out loud or
given as a numeral.

6BD27BB6B4644CA487BC5C471E5AF845.description:
Create different decompositions for a given quantity using
concrete manipulatives or pictures and explain orally how the
different decompositions represent the original quantity.

1BB36B880BDE4BD288B2D5C31BF5A1A6.description:
Identify whole numbers to 100 stated as a numeral or word
form in everyday situations and read the number out loud
(e.g., 24 on the classroom door would be read as twenty-four,
and read out loud “seventy-three” when found in a piece of
writing being read in class).

64ED3E26781F483BB2FFB03B95879A2D.description:
Represent quantities to 100 using non-proportional materials
(e.g., stir sticks and popsicle sticks, and coins) and explain
how the representation relates to the numeral used to
represent the quantity.

927B32F91B8545C584F50BF17EF5657C.description:
Represent quantities to 100 using proportional materials (e.g.,
tallies, ten frames, and base ten blocks) and explain how the
representation relates to the numeral used to represent the
quantity.

EED6D294DC294FE48566AAB33EC7AFA5.description:
Pose and solve problems that explore the quantity of whole
numbers to 100 (e.g., a student might wonder: “How many
pets would there be if everyone in the class brought their
pets to class”).

41FA8C4053A34F38978F234E7292779D.description:
Describe the meaning of quantities to 100 by relating them
to self, family, or community and explain what effect each
successive numeral position has on the actual quantity.

42FFA612365C499AB6ADB0037C573DE5.description:
Describe the patterns related to quantity and place value of
adjacent digit positions moving from right to left within a
whole number.

B965B0A66E4D44A386831F4907267AF5.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of whole
numbers to 100 (concretely,
pictorially, physically, orally, in
writing, and symbolically) by:
• representing (including
place value)
• describing
• skip counting
• differentiating between
odd and even numbers
• estimating with referents
• comparing two numbers
• ordering three or more
numbers.
[C, CN, ME, PS, R, V]
